Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-Functional Particle Assemblies in Polymer Nanocomposites
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The PI will design multi-functional polymer composites displaying self-assembled nanostructures with tunable mechanical and electrical properties in this CAREER project. The project aims to construct equilibrium magnetic nanostructures in which their multi-functional properties can be varied and optimized with the intermolecular forces. Polymer decorated iron oxide nanoparticles are a comprehensive model system offering both anisotropic and isotropic interactions that can be tuned with particle size, particle functionality (e.g. length and density of grafted chains, ions or bioligands) and external magnetic fields. This research plan will explain the role of various interactions and elucidate the formation of thermodynamically equilibrium self-assembled structures through non-linear rheology, scattering and microscopy. The PI proposes to investigate the fundamentals of the self-assembly mechanism for three-dimensional structures and their novel reversible self-assembly behavior. The role of conformational entropy of polymer chains on the assembly mechanism will be also examined. In addition, the phase diagram for a mixture of particles with different sizes will be studied to achieve complex novel structures other than obtained from monomodal particle sizes. Cluster organization kinetics and transition from disordered to ordered structures will be measured in-situ to underpin the stability of equilibrium states and reversibility of complex architectures.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The proposed research will offer a promising and simple synthesis and processing method to make multi-functional nanomaterials which can be used for applications requiring enhanced mechanical and electrical properties. This CAREER project will open new routes to the self-assembly of magnetic nanoparticles which can be applied to self-healing membranes and composites with tunable properties. The results will have an impact on design of new polymeric composites as they behave akin to smart materials, such as stimuli-responsive copolymers sensitive to pH and temperature or materials in which the conductivity and transduction properties change with the arrangement of particles. Moreover, the reversible self-assembly concept will have potential applications in biocompatible materials, mechanical sensors, highly reinforced compounds and new energetic materials. The fundamental nanoscale interactions and their impact on the mesoscale properties (e.g. combined mechanical and conductive properties in one material) of flexible polymer nanocomposites will be explored.

Within the course of this project, the PI plans to educate and train high school science teachers by offering research experiences in her laboratory to develop a collaborative science project for high school science curricula. To foster the interest of underrepresented students in science, research and engineering, she will work with the Society of Women Engineers and disseminate her research findings in their local and regional meetings and outreach activities. The PI will integrate her research activities into teaching of polymer science and will also actively engage undergraduate students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Multi-functional Particle Assemblies in Polymer Nanocomposites

 

The graduate student, Yang Jiao, has completed her Ph.D. work on this project. She worked on understanding the aggregation and organization of polymer decorated magnetic nanoparticle systems. Other two graduate students have also worked on several parts of the project to reveal the role of interphase and interface effects on magnetic particle assembly and to understand dispersion - mechanical property relationships and responses to applied shear and deformation. The major outcome of the synthesized polymeric brushes with magnetic cores was that various structures with magnetic building units can be formed other than anisotropic aggregates and these particle structures find their applications as membranes for nanofiltrations and ionically conductive membranes for energy applications. We utilized various interactions of ionic, magnetic, polymeric and van der Waals to design hybrid nanomaterials with tunable conductive and mechanical properties through controlling particle ordering. Our results on this project offers a unique way of controlling ionic aggregation in polymer composite/gel systems, which has critical importance in ways of designing ionomers into effective polyelectrolytes.

 

We presented that polystyrene-grafted iron oxide (superparamagnetic) nanofillers at low polymer grafting densities form highly ordered structures in their composites. Some of the interesting findings and outcomes of this project are summarized as follows: We demonstrated, for the first time, that well-ordered strings of particles are formed in 3-dimensional bulk composites (Figure 1). Anisotropic assemblies of superparamagnetic nanoparticles are controlled mainly by interfacial entanglements which are accessible only at low graft densities. Particles grafted with long chains are oriented in shear flow in bulk composites. Bridging between grafted chains and dipolar forces become effective only at low grafting density and result in long strings of particles. Chain conformations in string forming particles are reported, for the first time, using small-angle neutron and X-ray scattering. Polymer-grafted nanoparticles with ionic ends are designed. Location of ionic groups controls the assembly of side-by-side connected strings. Ionic interactions induce sheet-like network formation of nanoparticles. Polymer-grafted nanoparticles with very low sulfonation amounts are shown to be more conductive than sulfonated diblock copolymers and other conventional Nafion based proton conductive membranes. This finding is applied for a patent. Ionically functionalized nanoparticles in ionic liquids can enhance the mechanical properties through i) the less water-uptake due to low sulfonic amounts ii) anisotropic planar-like networks of the particles. Designing ionomers into effective polyelectrolytes is possible through our method by ionic-induced structures of polymer-grafted nanoparticles.

 

The project has interesting outcomes on observing the chain desorption and re-adsorption processes in attractive composites under shear. We showed that long chains of adsorbed layers led to a denser entangled interphase layer and can effectively enhance the bulk microscopic mechanical properties. We showed on an attractive polymer nanocomposite system that the bound layer interactions are tuned upon adsorbing homopolymers of bimodal chain lengths on nanoparticles. Subsequent changes in interfacial entanglement density enhanced the elastic properties of nanocomposites.

 

Akcora has worked with a high school science teacher from Morristown High School-New Jersey during the entire life of this grant, on the high school curriculum development for a unique new course titled “Nanoscale Science & Engineering”. Nanoscale Science &...

Akcora has worked with a high school science teacher from Morristown High School-New Jersey during the entire life of this grant, on the high school curriculum development for a unique new course titled "Nanoscale Science & Engineering". Nanoscale Science & Engineering course incorporates nanoscience labs developed through NSF-funded research to facilitate understanding of nanoscience and nanomaterials at a level appropri...
